Just as the roadworks was coming to an end, I saw a deer standing in the center median. Because I was concerned that the deer might run out in front of me - I had to make a snap decision as to whether I could quickly move into the right lane (because the roadworks had MAYBE just ended maybe I’d clip a traffic cone or something) or whether to brake hard (risking aquaplaning on the wet road) - or whether to just continue to drive ahead, only slowing more gently and hoping that the deer didn’t move.I did the latter…but that’s not important here.SO HOW CAN A SELF-DRIVING CAR KNOW WHAT TO DO?So think about how the software to make a car that drives itself could be programmed to deal with that situation?If the software was written conventionally - by computer programmers - the odds are VERY good that they’d never have thought of this very specific three-way choice situation. The software wouldn’t be able to cope with it for sure.So that’s NOT how self-driving car software works.Instead they use Artificial Intelligence techniques - where a very generic piece of software called a “Neural Network” kinda emulates the way that human and animal brains work.Neural Networks have to be trained by example. So, the “Pluribus” AI software that recently ANNIHILATED all six of the world’s best Texas Hold’em poker players learned how to play by watching millions of games of Texas Hold’em played by real humans - and learning by example.TRAINING DATA:So self-driving cars have to be trained too…and that means feeding them video captured by cameras and other sensors on real cars being driven along real roads by human drivers.So, when Google (now Waymo), Uber, Apple and others started to work on self-driving cars, they built a handful of cars - fitted them out with cameras and such - and hired a bunch of people to drive them around to capture examples of people driving.Trouble is - you might drive your ENTIRE LIFE and never see a deer, in the median, with traffic cones to your right while in the pouring rain.Waymo have now gotten about 6 million miles of real-world driving data with which to train their AI software. I very much doubt if a situation sufficiently similar to mine ever happened to them in all six million miles they drove. It might take billions of miles of driving for a sufficiently similar problem to show up.That’s a very serious problem. Paying people to drive even millions of miles is a costly proposition.WHAT TESLA DID:When Tesla started out - they had a cleverer solution. They’d make cars that couldn’t self-drive - but which had the computers, cameras and sensors to ALLOW them to do that once the AI software was sufficiently well trained.They started selling cars with only VERY limited self-driving abilities - hoping that people would trust them enough to pay extra for all of that stuff - with only a promise that self-driving would become functional and useful sometime in the future.That might not have worked if the cars weren’t pretty decent all-electric cars to start with…but it worked.So as Tesla sell more and more cars (about 300,000 per year right now) - and people are driving tens of thousands of miles in them - they are collecting about a BILLION miles of actual driving data every year.Next year - when they sell their 600,000’th car - they’ll collect TWO BILLION more miles.Every year - they’ll be gathering data a thousand times faster than their competitors in the self-driving field.This enables them to train their AI software on more and more obscure situations…and it’s very likely that they saw my Deer+Rain+Roadworks situation yesterday and that their AI software is already starting to learn about what to do.Over the next few billions of miles of road data - they’ll probably see many more similar situations and see how many other human drivers react to it.Ultimately, sometime in the next year or two - their AI will be able to handle that exact situation without problems.CHASING THE 9’s:Tesla have described this process as “chasing the 9’s”. Their current self-driving software only works on freeways - and it requires a human driver to be ready to take over at any moment if there is a problem.Nobody believes that self-driving cars will ever be 100% safe - but they don’t need to be. So long as they are significantly safer than human drivers - that’s “good enough”.I would say that - as of today (Nov. 2019) - that software is probably 99% likely to be able to drive safely for one mile along a freeway without a human jumping in to help. I drove about 100 self-driving miles on my car yesterday and had to intervene just once when it started changing lanes back and forth for no obvious reason. I don’t let it self-drive around roadworks yet though…so it wasn’t involved with the ‘deer incident’…and waiting just in case the AI might make a mistake is kinda nerve-wracking - more exhausting than just driving the car myself, so I don’t self-drive for most of the time.But 99% is nowhere near good enough! Neither is 99.9% or 99.99%. Fatal accident rates on freeways are about 12 deaths per billion miles driven - so the AI has to be significantly better than that - but is it 99 and eight more 9’s or do we need ten or twelve more 9’s?CONCLUSION: SO WHEN WILL WE HAVE FULL-SELF-DRIVING CARS?The problem spins three ways:All three of those things have to turn out just right - and predicting when that will all come together is hard to say.
